<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Whereas the reaction of 2,3,5,6-tetrakis-(carboxymethylthio)-benzenediol (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in a 1:2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M ratio resulted in the esterification of the carboxylic acid groups and the oxidation of quinol to quinone, the reaction in a 1:4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M ratio produced a 1-D coordination polymer, [Ag<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Whereas the reaction of 2,3,5,6-tetrakis-(carboxymethylthio)-benzenediol (H2 L) and AgNO3 in a 1:2M ratio resulted in the esterification of the carboxylic acid groups and the oxidation of quinol to quinone, the reaction in a 1:4M ratio produced a 1-D coordination polymer, [AgL 1(NO3)] n .

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:link id="lk00025" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538717305661/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">We describe the synthesis of a unique 1-D silver coordination polymer, in which the silver metal center is, unusually, six-coordinated. The reaction of 2,3,5,6-tetrakis-(carboxymethylthio)-benzenediol (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in a 1:2 ratio resulted in the esterification of the carboxylic acid groups and the oxidation of quinol to quinone. As a result, a methylesterthioquinone ligand (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>) was obtained. By increasing the molar ratio of Ag to four equivalents, a 1-D coordination polymer, [Ag<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), was obtained. The simple reaction of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in a 1:2 ratio also produced complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in quantitative yield. Both the esterified ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and the coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were fully characterized by infrared and <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, electrospray ionization mass spectrometry, and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that the Ag metal center has an octahedral geometry with <ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-nitrate ligands. The photophysical properties of complexes are also explored.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

We describe the synthesis of a unique 1-D silver coordination polymer, in which the silver metal center is, unusually, six-coordinated. The reaction of 2,3,5,6-tetrakis-(carboxymethylthio)-benzenediol (H2 L) and AgNO3 in a 1:2 ratio resulted in the esterification of the carboxylic acid groups and the oxidation of quinol to quinone. As a result, a methylesterthioquinone ligand (L1 ) was obtained. By increasing the molar ratio of Ag to four equivalents, a 1-D coordination polymer, [AgL 1(NO3)] n  (1), was obtained. The simple reaction of L1  and AgNO3 in a 1:2 ratio also produced complex 1 in quantitative yield. Both the esterified ligand L1  and the coordination polymer 1 were fully characterized by infrared and 1H NMR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, electrospray ionization mass spectrometry, and single crystal X-ray crystallography. The single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that the Ag metal center has an octahedral geometry with η 2-nitrate ligands. The photophysical properties of complexes are also explored.

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Interest in the development of molecular electronic devices  and redox substances has increased. For this purpose, coordination polymers (CP’s) of d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes have attracted significant interest. These CP’s not only offer diverse topologies and remarkable structural features but also have applications in sensing , gas storage , selective heterogeneous catalysis , and magnetic devices . In CP’s, the molecular electronic characteristics of the ligands in combination with the coordination geometry of the metal yield unique properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Interest in the development of molecular electronic devices  and redox substances has increased. For this purpose, coordination polymers (CP's) of d10 metal complexes have attracted significant interest. These CP's not only offer diverse topologies and remarkable structural features but also have applications in sensing , gas storage , selective heterogeneous catalysis , and magnetic devices . In CP's, the molecular electronic characteristics of the ligands in combination with the coordination geometry of the metal yield unique properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">There are various factors controlling the synthesis of CP’s, such as the metal/ligand ratio, concentration, temperature, and type of counterion used. However, the choice of metal and the design of the ligand are the most important factors. Ag is widely employed for the construction of CP’s because its CP’s have flexible geometries, variable coordination numbers, π interactions, and unusual electronic and photophysical characteristics . To date, various multidentate organic ligands have been synthesized with different properties. Sulfur-containing compounds, such as aromatic poly(phenylthio) ligands, have been explored because of their electron-accepting and delocalizing electrochemical properties . Many thio-substituted benzene ligands have been studied for the construction of Ag(I) CP’s. The soft nature of sulfur-containing ligands and silver results in interesting combinations for the design of CP’s .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: There are various factors controlling the synthesis of CP's, such as the metal/ligand ratio, concentration, temperature, and type of counterion used. However, the choice of metal and the design of the ligand are the most important factors. Ag is widely employed for the construction of CP's because its CP's have flexible geometries, variable coordination numbers, π interactions, and unusual electronic and photophysical characteristics . To date, various multidentate organic ligands have been synthesized with different properties. Sulfur-containing compounds, such as aromatic poly(phenylthio) ligands, have been explored because of their electron-accepting and delocalizing electrochemical properties . Many thio-substituted benzene ligands have been studied for the construction of Ag(I) CP's. The soft nature of sulfur-containing ligands and silver results in interesting combinations for the design of CP's .

In our work, we found that the metal to ligand ratio is very important for the synthesis of the 1-D coordination polymer. The use of ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> with two equivalents of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in MeOH led to the oxidation of the quinol ligand to quinone with the simultaneous esterification of the carboxylic acid groups present in the ligand. The reaction of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and the ligand in a 4:1 ratio in MeOH resulted in the formation of dark red crystals of a nitrate-bridged Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> coordination polymer. In this crystal, the geometry of silver metal center is octahedral, which is very unusual . Furthermore, we explored the photophysical properties of the octahedral Ag(I) 1-D coordination polymer.</ce:para>

The reaction of AgNO3 and the ligand in a 4:1 ratio in MeOH resulted in the formation of dark red crystals of a nitrate-bridged AgI coordination polymer. In this crystal, the geometry of silver metal center is octahedral, which is very unusual . Furthermore, we explored the photophysical properties of the octahedral Ag(I) 1-D coordination polymer.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

The synthesis of our target molecule was achieved as shown in  . The quinol ligand (2,4,5-tris-carboxymethylsulfanyl-3,6-dihydroxy-phenylsulfanyl)-acetic acid (H2 L) was synthesized following a literature procedure , and its reactions with AgI salts were methodically explored to obtain the ligand L1  and coordination polymer AgL1 (). The reaction of ligand H2 L in MeOH with two equivalents of AgNO3 at 60°C led to the oxidation of the quinol ligand to quinone with the simultaneous esterification of the carboxylate groups present in the ligand. The new ligand, L1 , crystallized overnight directly from the reaction mixture as a red solid suitable for X-ray analysis. The yield was ~46%. Subsequently, we repeated the reaction with an excess of AgNO3 compared to the previous reactions. The reaction of AgNO3 and the ligand in 4:1 ratio in MeOH at 60°C produced a reddish-brown solution and an ivory-colored powder. Dark-red crystals of nitrate-bridged AgI coordination polymer () were identified as the major product in ~42% yield. In these reaction systems, two equivalents of AgNO3 were used for the oxidation of quinol to quinone, and the remaining two equivalents of AgNO3 participated in the formation of the complex. The reaction of AgNO3 and L1  in a molar ratio of 2:1 also produced the desired product, [AgL 1(NO3)] n  (1). We further tried the reaction with excess AgNO3; however, we have failed to isolate any characterizable product. Various synthetic conditions and reaction systems were explored with different stoichiometries before a reproducible synthetic procedure was established.

</ce:bold> shows two sets of peaks that can be attributed to the presence of quinone forms in solution. The peaks at 3.717 and 3.561<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be assigned to the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and –CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> protons of the quinone form of the ligand. The use of higher molar ratio AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> not only resulted in the complexation of Ag and L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> but also complete oxidation of quinol to quinone.</ce:para>

The peaks at 3.717 and 3.561ppm can be assigned to the -CH2 and -CH3 protons of the quinone form of the ligand. The 1H NMR results of the 1 crystal also shows that only single complex is present in solution. <ce:section-title id="st035">Solid state structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The esterified ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The crystal structure of ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> shows that the thiocarbonyl acid has been esterified and the quinol group has been converted to quinone. Unlike the solution state <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR results, which indicate that both quinone and quinol are present in solution, the solid product contains only the quinone form. This indicates that the quinone form of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> is more energetically stable and precipitates preferentially. The crystal structure shows that two of the four methylthioester arms are directed inward, while the other two are directed outward. The bond angles between the sulfur atoms and benzene carbon atoms range from 101.7(2)° to 104.6(2)° (a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solid state structures

The esterified ligand L1  crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c ( ). The crystal structure of ligand L1  shows that the thiocarbonyl acid has been esterified and the quinol group has been converted to quinone. Unlike the solution state 1H NMR results, which indicate that both quinone and quinol are present in solution, the solid product contains only the quinone form. This indicates that the quinone form of L1  is more energetically stable and precipitates preferentially. The crystal structure shows that two of the four methylthioester arms are directed inward, while the other two are directed outward. The bond angles between the sulfur atoms and benzene carbon atoms range from 101.7(2)° to 104.6(2)° (a).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The [Ag<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> CP crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit of the complex consists of a ligand molecule, a silver atom, and a nitrate ion (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Ag atom is coordinated by six atoms, four S atoms from two molecules of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and two O from the nitrate ion, thus exhibiting an octahedral geometry with bond angles around the Ag(1) cation ranging from 51.8(3)° to 141.4(7)°. The coordination of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> with the thioester group of the ligand rather than the O from the quinone group present at the para position agrees well with the “hard and soft acids and bases” (HSAB) theory. Interestingly, the Ag center in this crystal has a rare octahedral geometry. The silver center is bonded to two S atoms from the ligand and two oxygen atoms from nitrate ion. b shows the helical 1D coordination polymer chain for the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The additional S⋯S (green dotted line) and S⋯O (pink dotted line) interactions assemble units of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> into sheets in the (0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0) plane (c and d). Additional weak CH⋯O interactions (e) result in a 3-D network structure ((e). The η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-nitrate does not participate in the extended chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The [AgL1 (NO3)] n  CP crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit of the complex consists of a ligand molecule, a silver atom, and a nitrate ion ( a). The Ag atom is coordinated by six atoms, four S atoms from two molecules of L 1 and two O from the nitrate ion, thus exhibiting an octahedral geometry with bond angles around the Ag(1) cation ranging from 51.8(3)° to 141.4(7)°. The coordination of Ag1 with the thioester group of the ligand rather than the O from the quinone group present at the para position agrees well with the "hard and soft acids and bases" (HSAB) theory. Interestingly, the Ag center in this crystal has a rare octahedral geometry. The silver center is bonded to two S atoms from the ligand and two oxygen atoms from nitrate ion. b shows the helical 1D coordination polymer chain for the 1. The additional S⋯S (green dotted line) and S⋯O (pink dotted line) interactions assemble units of 1 into sheets in the (010) plane (c and d). Additional weak CH⋯O interactions (e) result in a 3-D network structure ((e). The η2-nitrate does not participate in the extended chains.

<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In order to investigate the bulk properties of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, TGA experiments were conducted and the thermograms were obtained as shown in . The thermal degradation of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> consist of three weight loss steps, where the first and second weight loss below 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C could be ascribed to partial decomposition of ester groups. The third weight loss could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the remaining sulfur and quinone part. The thermal degradation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides more complicated five step weigh loss. The first weight loss below 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C seems to be the evaporation of solvents. The second, third and forth weight loss steps could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the ester groups and remaining organic parts, respectively.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis spectra

To investigate the photophysical properties of both the ligand and complex, UV-Vis spectra were obtained. ( ) In the spectrum of ligand H2 L, the absorption maximum peaks (λ max) are found at 244 and 351nm, having molar extinction coefficients of 67500 and 16300M-1 cm-1, respectively ( ). These values can be attributed to the π-π∗ and n-π∗ electronic transitions taking place in H2 L. The esterified ligand, L1 , which has a quinone group, has λ max values at 228 and 370nm, and the molar extinction coefficient values for L1  are 46300 and 30100M-1 cm-1, respectively. The λ max at 228nm shows a hypsochromic shift of 16nm with a decrease in the absorption intensity compared to that of H2 L. The value of λ max at 370nm shows a bathochromic shift of 19nm with an increase in the absorption intensity in comparison with that of H2 L. The shift of λ max and change in absorption intensities can be attributed to the new structural features in L1  , that is, the change of functional group from an acid to ester group and the oxidation of quinol to quinone.

elements.content:

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. These values indicate an inter-ligand electronic transition , i.e., π-π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> and n-π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>. The absorption maxima of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> show a hypsochromic shift of 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and a bathochromic shift of 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm compared to those of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>. In contrast, there is a clear decrease in the absorption intensity of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> spectra as compared to that of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>. This could be because, in the solution state, <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> contains both quinone and unoxidized quinol forms, as shown by NMR. However, in the case of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, only the quinone form of the ligand is present.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the spectrum of 1, λ max are found at 211 and 378nm, and the molar extinction coefficients are 29500 and 12500M-1 cm-1, respectively. These values indicate an inter-ligand electronic transition , i.e., π-π∗ and n-π∗. The absorption maxima of 1 show a hypsochromic shift of 17nm and a bathochromic shift of 8nm compared to those of L1 . In contrast, there is a clear decrease in the absorption intensity of the 1 spectra as compared to that of L1 . This could be because, in the solution state, L1  contains both quinone and unoxidized quinol forms, as shown by NMR. However, in the case of complex 1, only the quinone form of the ligand is present.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st045">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">In this paper, we demonstrated that by using a 1:2 ratio of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, the carboxylic acid group can be esterified and the quinol can be oxidized to a quinone, resulting in the isolation of crystals of the methylesterthioquinone ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>

elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we demonstrated that by using a 1:2 ratio of H2 L and AgNO3, the carboxylic acid group can be esterified and the quinol can be oxidized to a quinone, resulting in the isolation of crystals of the methylesterthioquinone ligand L1 . We further doubled the molar ratio of AgNO3, and, surprisingly, a 1-D coordination polymer, [AgL1 (NO3)] n  was obtained. Unlike the typical low coordination numbers and related geometries of silver coordination compounds, the Ag center was found to have an octahedral geometry. Furthermore photophysical properties of H2 L, L1  and complex 1 were investigated. The results dictate that inter-ligand electronic transition takes place in complex 1 when exposed to UV-Vis light.

Synthesis

Ligand H2L

The ligand was prepared following a modified literature procedure . p-Benzoquinone (2g, 20mmol) was placed in 10mL of water, and thioglycolic acid (5.41mL, 80mmol) in water was added very slowly, as mentioned in the literature, over 30min. Immediately after the complete addition of thioglycolic acid, the brown solution became white. The product, a white powder, was obtained and separated by filtration and recrystallized from hot water. Yield 56%, IR peaks: 3340 (br), 1701 (s), 1431 (m), 1382 (m), 1310 (m), 1198 (m), 865 (w). 1H NMR DMSO-d 6: 3.72 (s, -CH2).

Ligand H2L (47.05mg, 0.1mmol), silver nitrate (34mg, 0.2mmol), and MeOH (5mL) were charged into a 50-mL round bottom flask. The color of the reaction mixture became ivory. Elemental analyses (CHN) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer model 240C elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 883 spectrometer. A solute concentration of 10-3 M was used, and a Shimadzu UV 3100 UV-Vis-NIR spectrophotometer was used to record the electronic absorption spectra.

<ce:section-title id="st080">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Suitable single crystals of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were examined using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a fine focus 1.75-kW sealed-tube Mo-K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation generator (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>) 0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The data were collected at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, by scanning ω in steps of 0.3° at a scan speed of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s per frame. The APEX2 software was used for data acquisition and data integration and reduction . Structures were solved by direct methods using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-2014 and refined with full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-2014 . The locations of the heaviest atoms (Ag) were easily determined, and the O, N, and C atoms were subsequently determined from the difference Fourier maps. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometries and riding thermal parameters with respect to their carrier atoms. A summary of the crystal data and relevant refinement parameters are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of L and 1 were examined using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a fine focus 1.75-kW sealed-tube Mo-Kα radiation generator (λ) 0.71073Å. The data were collected at 298K, by scanning ω in steps of 0.3° at a scan speed of 5s per frame. The APEX2 software was used for data acquisition and data integration and reduction . Structures were solved by direct methods using shelxs-2014 and refined with full-matrix least squares on F 2 using shelxl-2014 . The locations of the heaviest atoms (Ag) were easily determined, and the O, N, and C atoms were subsequently determined from the difference Fourier maps. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometries and riding thermal parameters with respect to their carrier atoms. A summary of the crystal data and relevant refinement parameters are given in  .

<ce:section-title id="st035">Solid state structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The esterified ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The crystal structure of ligand <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> shows that the thiocarbonyl acid has been esterified and the quinol group has been converted to quinone. Unlike the solution state <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR results, which indicate that both quinone and quinol are present in solution, the solid product contains only the quinone form. This indicates that the quinone form of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> is more energetically stable and precipitates preferentially. The crystal structure shows that two of the four methylthioester arms are directed inward, while the other two are directed outward. The bond angles between the sulfur atoms and benzene carbon atoms range from 101.7(2)° to 104.6(2)° (a).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In order to investigate the bulk properties of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, TGA experiments were conducted and the thermograms were obtained as shown in . The thermal degradation of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> consist of three weight loss steps, where the first and second weight loss below 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C could be ascribed to partial decomposition of ester groups. The third weight loss could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the remaining sulfur and quinone part. The thermal degradation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides more complicated five step weigh loss. The first weight loss below 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C seems to be the evaporation of solvents. cln_elements.clean_text:
Solid state structures

The esterified ligand L1  crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c ( ). The crystal structure of ligand L1  shows that the thiocarbonyl acid has been esterified and the quinol group has been converted to quinone. Unlike the solution state 1H NMR results, which indicate that both quinone and quinol are present in solution, the solid product contains only the quinone form. This indicates that the quinone form of L1  is more energetically stable and precipitates preferentially. The crystal structure shows that two of the four methylthioester arms are directed inward, while the other two are directed outward. The bond angles between the sulfur atoms and benzene carbon atoms range from 101.7(2)° to 104.6(2)° (a).

In order to investigate the bulk properties of L1  and complex 1, TGA experiments were conducted and the thermograms were obtained as shown in . The thermal degradation of L1  consist of three weight loss steps, where the first and second weight loss below 350°C could be ascribed to partial decomposition of ester groups. The third weight loss could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the remaining sulfur and quinone part. The thermal degradation of 1 provides more complicated five step weigh loss. The first weight loss below 150°C seems to be the evaporation of solvents. The second, third and forth weight loss steps could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the ester groups and remaining organic parts, respectively.

UV-Vis spectra

To investigate the photophysical properties of both the ligand and complex, UV-Vis spectra were obtained. ( ) In the spectrum of ligand H2 L, the absorption maximum peaks (λ max) are found at 244 and 351nm, having molar extinction coefficients of 67500 and 16300M-1 cm-1, respectively ( ). These values can be attributed to the π-π∗ and n-π∗ electronic transitions taking place in H2 L. The esterified ligand, L1 , which has a quinone group, has λ max values at 228 and 370nm, and the molar extinction coefficient values for L1  are 46300 and 30100M-1 cm-1, respectively. The λ max at 228nm shows a hypsochromic shift of 16nm with a decrease in the absorption intensity compared to that of H2 L. The value of λ max at 370nm shows a bathochromic shift of 19nm with an increase in the absorption intensity in comparison with that of H2 L. The shift of λ max and change in absorption intensities can be attributed to the new structural features in L1  , that is, the change of functional group from an acid to ester group and the oxidation of quinol to quinone.

In the spectrum of 1, λ max are found at 211 and 378nm, and the molar extinction coefficients are 29500 and 12500M-1 cm-1, respectively. These values indicate an inter-ligand electronic transition , i.e., π-π∗ and n-π∗. The absorption maxima of 1 show a hypsochromic shift of 17nm and a bathochromic shift of 8nm compared to those of L1 . In contrast, there is a clear decrease in the absorption intensity of the 1 spectra as compared to that of L1 . This could be because, in the solution state, L1  contains both quinone and unoxidized quinol forms, as shown by NMR. However, in the case of complex 1, only the quinone form of the ligand is present.
